code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union aus_mortality |>   filter(State == "Victoria", Sex == "female") |>   model(mean = FMEAN(Mortality)) #> # A mable: 1 x 4 #> # Key:     Sex, State, Code [1] #>   Sex    State    Code     mean #>   <chr>  <chr>    <chr> <model> #> 1 female Victoria VIC   <FMEAN>

what: Coerce to a vital object — as_vital
title: Coerce to a vital object — as_vital
text: vital object type tsibble contains vital statistics births, deaths, population counts, mortality fertility rates. tsibble special class allows special methods used. object attribute stores variables names needed functions, including age, sex, births, deaths population.

title: Coerce to a vital object — as_vital
code: as_vital(x, ...)  # S3 method for demogdata as_vital(x, sex_groups = TRUE, ...)  # S3 method for tbl_ts as_vital(   x,   .age = NULL,   .sex = NULL,   .deaths = NULL,   .births = NULL,   .population = NULL,   reorder = FALSE,   ... )  # S3 method for data.frame as_vital(   x,   key = NULL,   index,   .age = NULL,   .sex = NULL,   .deaths = NULL,   .births = NULL,   .population = NULL,   ... )

title: Coerce to a vital object — as_vital
text: x Object coerced vital format. ... arguments passed as_tsibble sex_groups Logical variable indicating groups denote sexes .age Name age variable .sex Name sex variable .deaths Name deaths variable .births Name births variable .population Name population variable reorder Logical indicating variables reordered. key Variable(s) uniquely determine time indices. NULL empty key, c() multiple variables. works tidy selector (e.g. starts_with()). index variable specify time index variable.

title: Coerce to a vital object — as_vital
text: vital object.

code: library(ggplot2) aus_mortality #> # A vital: 280,881 x 8 [1Y] #> # Key:     Age, Sex, State, Code [2,727] #>     Year   Age Sex    State     Code  Mortality Exposure Deaths #>    <int> <int> <chr>  <chr>     <chr>     <dbl>    <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1  1901     0 female Australia AUS     0.103      46315   4780 #>  2  1901     1 female Australia AUS     0.0231     42345    978 #>  3  1901     2 female Australia AUS     0.00694    41766    290 #>  4  1901     3 female Australia AUS     0.00453    42635    193 #>  5  1901     4 female Australia AUS     0.00376    42774    161 #>  6  1901     5 female Australia AUS     0.00299    44160    132 #>  7  1901     6 female Australia AUS     0.00259    44747    116 #>  8  1901     7 female Australia AUS     0.00218    45515     99 #>  9  1901     8 female Australia AUS     0.00185    45437     84 #> 10  1901     9 female Australia AUS     0.00144    45911     66 #> # ℹ 280,871 more rows aus_mortality |>   dplyr::filter(State=="Victoria", Sex != "total") |>   rainbow_plot(Exposure/1000) +   ylab("Population at 30 June (thousands)")

what: Produce forecasts from a vital model — forecast.model_fmean
title: Produce forecasts from a vital model — forecast.model_fmean
text: forecast function allows produce future predictions functional time series model, response function age. response variable transformed model formula, transformation automatically back-transformed bias-adjusted. details transformations fable framework can found `vignette("transformations", package = "fable")`.

title: Produce forecasts from a vital model — forecast.model_fmean
code: # S3 method for model_fmean forecast(object, new_data, bootstrap = FALSE, times = 5000, ...)

title: Produce forecasts from a vital model — forecast.model_fmean
text: object mable containing one models. new_data `tsibble` containing future information used forecast. bootstrap `TRUE`, forecast distributions computed using simulation resampled errors. times number sample paths use estimating forecast distribution `bootstrap = TRUE`. ... Additional arguments used. #'

title: Produce forecasts from a vital model — forecast.model_fmean
text: fable containing following columns: - `.model`: name model used obtain forecast. Taken   column names models provided mable. - forecast distribution. name column   dependent variable model(s). multiple dependent variables exist,   named `.distribution`. - Point forecasts computed distribution using functions   `point_forecast` argument. - columns `new_data`, excluding whose names conflict   .

title: Produce forecasts from a vital model — forecast.model_fmean
text: forecasts returned contain point forecasts distribution. specific forecast interval can extracted distribution using [`hilo()`] function, multiple intervals can obtained using [`report()`]. intervals stored single column using `hilo` class, extract numerical upper lower bounds can use [`unpack_hilo()`].

title: Forecasts using Lee-Carter method. — forecast.lc_model
text: kt coefficients forecast using random walk drift. forecast coefficients multiplied bx obtain forecast demographic rate curve.

title: Forecasts using Lee-Carter method. — forecast.lc_model
code: # S3 method for lc_model forecast(   object,   h = 50,   se = c("innovdrift", "innovonly"),   jumpchoice = c("fit", "actual"),   level = 80,   ... )

title: Forecasts using Lee-Carter method. — forecast.lc_model
text: object Output lee_carter. h Number years ahead forecast. se Method used computation standard error. Possibilities: “innovdrift” (innovations drift) “innovonly” (innovations ). jumpchoice Method used computation jumpchoice. Possibilities: “actual” (use actual rates final year) “fit” (use fitted rates). original Lee-Carter method used 'fit' (default), Lee Miller (2001) authors prefer 'actual' (default). level Confidence level prediction intervals. ... arguments.

title: Forecasts using Lee-Carter method. — forecast.lc_model
text: Object class fm_forecast following components: age Ages object. year Years object. rate List matrices containing forecasts, lower bound upper bound prediction intervals.   Point forecast matrix takes name series forecast. fitted Matrix one-step forecasts historical data components included e0 Forecasts life expectancies (including lower upper bounds) kt.f Forecasts coefficients model. type Data type. model Details fitted model

title: Forecasts using Lee-Carter method. — forecast.lc_model
text: Lee, R D, Carter, L R (1992) Modeling forecasting US mortality. Journal American Statistical Association, 87, 659-671. Lee R D, Miller T (2001). Evaluating performance Lee-Carter   method forecasting mortality. Demography, 38(4), 537–549.

title: Forecasts using Lee-Carter method. — forecast.lc_model
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Forecasts using Lee-Carter method. — forecast.lc_model
code: library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) ausf_lc <- aus_mortality |>   filter(Sex == "female", State == "Australia") |>   lee_carter() ausf_fcast <- forecast(ausf_lc, 50) ausf_fcast |>   filter(Age == 60) |>   autoplot(aus_mortality)  rainbow_plot(ausf_fcast, .vars = .mean) +   scale_y_log10()

what: Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
title: Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
text: Model mortality fertility data using functional principal components proposed Hyndman & Ullah (2007) Missing rates set geometric mean rate relevant age.

title: Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
text: .data vital object including age variable variable containing mortality fertility rates. rates Variable `.data` containing mortality fertility rates. omitted, search variable one following names: `mx`, `mortality`, `fx`, `fertility` `rate` (case sensitive). order Number principal components fit.

title: Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
text: list class fpc_model containing various model objects.

title: Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
text: Hyndman, R.J., Ullah, S. (2007) Robust forecasting mortality fertility rates: functional data approach. Computational Statistics & Data Analysis, 51, 4942-4956. https://robjhyndman.com/publications/funcfor/

title: Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
text: Rob J Hyndman.

title: Fit a functional principal components model — fpc_model
code: # Compute Hyndman-Ullah model for Australian females, males and total aus_hu <- aus_mortality |>   dplyr::filter(Code == "AUS") |>   fpc_model() aus_hu #> Functional data model #>  #> Sub-groups: #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   Sex    State     Code  varprop #>   <chr>  <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> #> 1 female Australia AUS     0.980 #> 2 male   Australia AUS     0.970 #> 3 total  Australia AUS     0.984 autoplot(aus_hu) +   patchwork::plot_annotation("Hyndman-Ullah components for Australia")

what: Generate responses from a mable — generate.mdl_vtl_df
title: Generate responses from a mable — generate.mdl_vtl_df
text: Use model's fitted distribution simulate additional data similar behaviour response. tidy implementation `simulate`.

title: Generate responses from a mable — generate.mdl_vtl_df
code: # S3 method for mdl_vtl_df generate(x, new_data = NULL, h = NULL, times = 1, seed = NULL, ...)  # S3 method for mdl_vtl_ts generate(   x,   new_data = NULL,   h = NULL,   times = 1,   seed = NULL,   bootstrap = FALSE,   bootstrap_block_size = 1,   ... )

title: Generate responses from a mable — generate.mdl_vtl_df
text: x mable. new_data data generated (time index exogenous regressors) h simulation horizon (can used instead `new_data` regular time series exogenous regressors). times number replications. seed seed random generation distributions. ... Additional arguments individual simulation methods. bootstrap TRUE, forecast distributions computed using simulation resampled errors. bootstrap_block_size bootstrap block size specifies number contiguous residuals taken bootstrap sample.

title: Generate responses from a mable — generate.mdl_vtl_df
text: Innovations sampled model's assumed error distribution. `bootstrap` `TRUE`, innovations sampled model's residuals. `new_data` contains `.innov` column, values treated innovations simulated paths..

what: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
title: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
text: Lee-Carter model mortality fertility rates. lee_carter produces standard Lee-Carter model default, although many options available. Missing rates set geometric mean rate relevant age.

title: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
code: lee_carter(.data, rates, adjust = c("dt", "dxt", "e0", "none"), scale = FALSE)

title: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
text: .data vital object including age variable variable containing mortality fertility rates. rates Variable `.data` containing mortality fertility rates. omitted, search variable one following names: `mx`, `mortality`, `fx`, `fertility` `rate` (case sensitive). adjust method use adjustment coefficients \(k_t kt\). Possibilities “dt” (Lee-Carter method, default), “dxt” (BMS method), “e0” (Lee-Miller method based life expectancy) “none”. scale TRUE, bx kt rescaled kt drift parameter = 1.

title: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
text: list class lc_model containing various model objects.

title: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
text: Basellini, U, Camarda, C G, Booth, H (2022) Thirty years : review Lee-Carter method forecasting mortality. Booth, H., Maindonald, J., Smith, L. (2002) Applying Lee-Carter conditions variable mortality decline. Population Studies, 56, 325-336. Lee, R D, Carter, L R (1992) Modeling forecasting US mortality. Journal American Statistical Association, 87, 659-671. Lee R D, Miller T (2001). Evaluating performance Lee-Carter   method forecasting mortality. Demography, 38(4), 537–549. International Journal Forecasting, appear.

title: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
text: Rob J Hyndman.

title: Model mortality or fertility data using Lee-Carter approach — lee_carter
code: # Compute Lee-Carter model for Australian females, males and total aus_lc <- aus_mortality |>   dplyr::filter(Code == "AUS") |>   lee_carter() aus_lc #> Lee-Carter model #>  #> Sub-groups: #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   Sex    State     Code  varprop adjust #>   <chr>  <chr>     <chr>   <dbl> <chr>  #> 1 female Australia AUS     0.941 dt     #> 2 male   Australia AUS     0.888 dt     #> 3 total  Australia AUS     0.935 dt     autoplot(aus_lc) +   patchwork::plot_annotation("Lee Carter components for Australia")  autoplot(aus_lc$time, kt)

what: Compute life expectancy from mortality rates — life_expectancy
title: Compute life expectancy from mortality rates — life_expectancy
text: Returns remaining life expectancy given age (0 default).

title: Compute life expectancy from mortality rates — life_expectancy
Compute life expectancy from mortality rates — life_expectancy
text: .data vital object including age variable variable containing mortality rates. from_age Age life expectancy calculated. Either scalar vector ages. mortality Variable `.data` containing Mortality rates (mx). omitted, variable name  `mx`, `Mortality` `Rate` used (case sensitive).

title: Compute life expectancy from mortality rates — life_expectancy
text: vital object life expectancy column `ex`.

title: Compute life expectancy from mortality rates — life_expectancy
text: Chiang CL. (1984) life table applications. Robert E Krieger Publishing Company: Malabar. Keyfitz, N, Caswell, H. (2005) Applied mathematical demography, Springer-Verlag: New York. Preston, S.H., Heuveline, P., Guillot, M. (2001) Demography: measuring modeling population processes. Blackwell

title: Compute life expectancy from mortality rates — life_expectancy
code: # Compute Australia life expectancy for females over time aus_mortality |>   dplyr::filter(Code == "AUS", Sex == "female") |>   life_expectancy() #> # A vital: 103 x 6 [1Y] #> # Key:     Age, Sex, State, Code [1] #>     Year Sex    State     Code     ex   Age #>    <int> <chr>  <chr>     <chr> <dbl> <int> #>  1  1901 female Australia AUS    56.3     0 #>  2  1902 female Australia AUS    55.8     0 #>  3  1903 female Australia AUS    56.4     0 #>  4  1904 female Australia AUS    58.7     0 #>  5  1905 female Australia AUS    59.8     0 #>  6  1906 female Australia AUS    59.5     0 #>  7  1907 female Australia AUS    59.6     0 #>  8  1908 female Australia AUS    59.8     0 #>  9  1909 female Australia AUS    61.4     0 #> 10  1910 female Australia AUS    61.2     0 #> # ℹ 93 more rows

what: Compute period lifetables from mortality rates — life_table
title: Compute period lifetables from mortality rates — life_table
text: available years ages included tables. qx = mx/(1 + ((1-ax) * mx)) per Chiang (1984). Warning: code tested data based single-year age groups.

title: Compute period lifetables from mortality rates — life_table
Compute period lifetables from mortality rates — life_table
text: .data vital including age variable variable containing mortality rates. mortality Variable `.data` containing Mortality rates (mx). omitted, variable name  `mx`, `Mortality` `Rate` used (case sensitive).

title: Compute period lifetables from mortality rates — life_table
text: vital object containing index, keys, new life table variables `mx`, `qx`, `lx`, `dx`, `Lx`, `Tx` `ex`.

title: Compute period lifetables from mortality rates — life_table
text: Chiang CL. (1984) life table applications. Robert E Krieger Publishing Company: Malabar. Keyfitz, N, Caswell, H. (2005) Applied mathematical demography, Springer-Verlag: New York. Preston, S.H., Heuveline, P., Guillot, M. (2001) Demography: measuring modeling population processes. Blackwell

title: Compute period lifetables from mortality rates — life_table

what: Estimate models for vital data — model.vital
title: Estimate models for vital data — model.vital
text: Trains specified model definition(s) dataset. function estimate set model definitions (passed via `...`) series within `.data` (identified key structure). result mable (model table), neatly stores estimated models tabular structure. Rows data identify different series within data, model column contains models model definition. cell mable identifies single model.

title: Estimate models for vital data — model.vital
code: # S3 method for vital model(.data, ..., .safely = TRUE)

title: Estimate models for vital data — model.vital
text: .data data structure suitable models (`tsibble`) ... Definitions models used. models must share response variable. .safely model encounters error, rather aborting process [NULL model][null_model()] returned instead. allows error occur computing many models, without losing results successful models.

title: Estimate models for vital data — model.vital
text: possible estimate models parallel using [future](https://cran.r-project.org/package=future) package. specifying [`future::plan()`] estimating models, computed according plan.

title: Estimate models for vital data — model.vital
text: Progress model estimation can obtained wrapping code `progressr::with_progress()`. customisation progress reported can controlled using `progressr` package.

what: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd
title: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd
text: read_hmd reads 1x1 data Human Mortality Database (HMD https://www.mortality.org) constructs vital object suitable use functions. function uses readHMDweb download required data.

title: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd
code: read_hmd(   country,   username,   password,   variables = c("Deaths", "Exposures", "Population", "Mx") )

title: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd
text: country Directory abbreviation HMD. instance, Australia = "AUS". username HMD username (case-sensitive) password HMD password (case-sensitive) variables List variables download HMD.

title: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd
text: read_hmd returns vital object following variables: Year Numerical vector containing year observation Age Numerical vector containing age group OpenInterval Logical vector indicating age interval open Sex Character vector taking values "Female", "Male", "Total" Deaths Total deaths Exposure Numerical vector exposure--risk, equal population size 30 June Population Numerical vector containing population size 1 January Mortality Numerical vector mortality rate, equal Deaths/Exposure

title: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd
text: order read data, users required create account HMD website (https://www.mortality.org), obtain valid username password.

title: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd
text: Rob J Hyndman

title: Read data directly from HMD and construct a vital object for use in other functions — read_hmd

what: vital: Tidy Analysis Tools for Mortality, Fertility, Migration and Population Data — vital-package
title: vital: Tidy Analysis Tools for Mortality, Fertility, Migration and Population Data — vital-package
text: Functions analysing vital statistics based tools consistent tidyverse. Tools provided data visualization, lifetable calculations, computing net migration numbers, Lee-Carter modelling; functional data modelling stochastic population forecasting.

title: vital: Tidy Analysis Tools for Mortality, Fertility, Migration and Population Data — vital-package
text: Maintainer: Rob Hyndman Rob.Hyndman@monash.edu (ORCID) [copyright holder] Authors: Mitchell O'Hara-Wild (ORCID)

title: Create a vital object — vital
text: vital object type tsibble contains vital statistics births, deaths, population counts, mortality fertility rates. tsibble special class allows special methods used. object attribute stores variables names needed functions, including age, sex, births, deaths population.

title: Create a vital object — vital
code: vital(   ...,   key = NULL,   index,   .age = NULL,   .sex = NULL,   .deaths = NULL,   .births = NULL,   .population = NULL,   regular = TRUE,   .drop = TRUE )

title: Create a vital object — vital
text: ... set name-value pairs key Variable(s) uniquely determine time indices. NULL empty key, c() multiple variables. works tidy selector (e.g. starts_with()). index variable specify time index variable. .age Name age variable .sex Name sex variable .deaths Name deaths variable .births Name births variable .population Name population variable regular Regular time interval (TRUE) irregular (FALSE). interval determined greatest common divisor index column, TRUE. .drop TRUE, empty key groups dropped.

title: Conflicts between vital packages and other packages — vital_conflicts
text: conflicts deliberately ignored: intersect, union, setequal, setdiff dplyr; intersect, union, setdiff, .difftime lubridate. functions make base equivalents generic, negatively affect existing code.

title: Conflicts between vital packages and other packages — vital_conflicts
code: vital_conflicts() #> ── Conflicts ──────────────────────────────────────────────── vital_conflicts ── #> ✖ dplyr::filter()      masks stats::filter() #> ✖ tsibble::intersect() masks base::intersect() #> ✖ dplyr::lag()         masks stats::lag() #> ✖ tsibble::setdiff()   masks base::setdiff() #> ✖ tsibble::union()     masks base::union()
